node.title: Youngkin’s Dance With Trump Was Pivotal. But Is It Repeatable?
node.alt: Glenn Youngkin won the Virginia governor’s race by fusing together a coalition of Trump partisans with anti-Trump moderates.
node.description: Glenn Youngkin’s victory in Virginia may inspire Republican imitators vying to win over Trump supporters without embracing the former president outright.
node.content: ["Since he burst onto the national political scene in 2015, Donald J. Trump has strong-armed one Republican after another into submission. But in Virginia, Glenn Youngkin did something new: He managed to keep the former president at a politically safe remove without alienating him or his allies.", "Mr. Youngkin\u2019s success in the Virginia governor\u2019s race speaks not only to his own deft handling of his party\u2019s volatile and unpredictable standard-bearer but also to Mr. Trump\u2019s apparent willingness to place himself on the sidelines during a campaign that received wall-to-wall coverage on cable news.", "What is not known is whether Mr. Youngkin\u2019s formula is repeatable elsewhere, particularly in the 2022 midterm elections. Mr. Trump has little track record of ceding the spotlight or allowing other Republicans to take credit for any political success, and there is little reason to expect that to change.", "Early on in his own campaign, Mr. Youngkin, a former private equity executive, recognized Mr. Trump\u2019s usefulness to his political prospects. In the spring, during the Republican nominating contest in Virginia, Mr. Youngkin echoed Mr. Trump\u2019s false claims of election fraud. After winning the G.O.P. nomination at a party convention in May, Mr. Trump endorsed him and Mr. Youngkin told a conservative radio host that he was honored.", "\u201cPresident Trump represents so much of why I\u2019m running,\u201d Mr. Youngkin said at the time.", "But thereafter, Mr. Youngkin mainly kept quiet about the former president. Mr. Trump, in turn, made no public demands of fealty and encouraged his Virginia supporters to flood the polls, something he refused to do ahead of the January special elections in Georgia that gave Democrats control of the Senate.", "Mr. Youngkin focused his campaign on education policy, eliminating taxes on groceries and gasoline, and other local issues that were hardly Trump priorities. He insisted that he planned to run his own race, staying away from two rallies that Mr. Trump called into. And he rarely spoke about the issues that used to motivate the Republican base, such as gun rights or opposing abortion.", "But embedded in his education policy was a pitch to the same white grievance politics that fueled Mr. Trump\u2019s campaign \u2014 an attack on critical race theory, a graduate-level academic framework that has become a stand-in for a debate over what to teach about race and racism in American schools. In Virginia, it served as a catchall rallying cry akin to the states\u2019 rights battles of generations past.", "And the Democrats seemed to help Mr. Youngkin more than Mr. Trump did.", "Mr. Youngkin did not need to remind Mr. Trump\u2019s supporters that the former president had backed him. His Democratic opponent, Terry McAuliffe, turned much of his campaign, and his closing argument above all, into a message tethering Mr. Trump and Mr. Youngkin together, a gambit designed to energize the Democratic base \u2014 which it did in Northern Virginia.", "Even President Biden joined in the Trump-bashing, speaking far more about his predecessor than his own agenda during a rally for Mr. McAuliffe last week in Arlington.", "\u201cThe reason I mentioned Trump,\u201d the president told reporters on Wednesday, was because issues that Mr. Trump supports, even while out of office, were \u201caffecting their lives every day and they\u2019re having a negative impact on their lives.\u201d", "Mr. Youngkin successfully fused the Republican Party\u2019s past and present, building a coalition of Trump partisans and moderates who disengaged with the G.O.P. during the former president\u2019s White House tenure.", "The Republican turnout on Tuesday \u2014 aided by an expansion of the mail-in and early-voting laws denounced by Mr. Trump \u2014 swamped what otherwise would have been a respectable showing by Mr. McAuliffe, whose total, while still being counted, showed he won at least 500,000 more votes than he received during his winning 2013 campaign.", "But Mr. Youngkin did a notch better, with his pro-Trump and anti-Trump coalition, a theme he hewed to during his victory remarks.", "\u201cTogether, together, together, together, we can build a new day,\u201d he said.", "Mr. Youngkin\u2019s triumph may inspire copycat Republicans eager to win the allegiance of Mr. Trump\u2019s supporters without a sustained public embrace of the former president. The tricky part will be doing so without alienating elements of the party critical to winning in competitive contests.", "As results poured in showing Mr. Youngkin ahead on Tuesday night, Mr. Trump issued three separate self-congratulatory statements. Then on Wednesday morning, Mr. Trump told John Fredericks, a conservative radio host and the chairman of his 2016 and 2020 campaigns in Virginia, that Mr. Youngkin would have been crushed without his support.", "\u201cWithout MAGA, he would have lost by 15 points or more,\u201d Mr. Trump said.", "Mr. Youngkin spent $20 million of his own money to subsidize television ads portraying him as a from-the-bootstraps business success, clad in a campaign-logo fleece vest that cemented his image as a suburban dad. Weeks later, Mr. McAuliffe began airing his own ads attacking Mr. Youngkin as a Trump acolyte.", "\u201cThe win is a credit to Glenn being a uniter and not a divider,\u201d said Barbara Comstock, a \u201cNever-Trump\u201d Republican in Northern Virginia and former congresswoman who backed Mr. Youngkin. \u201cHe understands politics is about addition while Trump is about subtraction and division.\u201d", "Yet while Mr. Youngkin\u2019s top political aide, Jeff Roe, maintained a line of communication to Mr. Trump\u2019s top political aide, Susie Wiles, the former president kept the Virginia campaign on edge in the weeks before Election Day.", "The two sides worked to arrange Mr. Trump\u2019s \u201ctele-rally\u201d on the eve of the election, according to an aide to Mr. Youngkin, but there was no coordination on what the former president would say. Mr. Trump managed not to undermine Mr. Youngkin\u2019s campaign themes.", "Mr. Fredericks, the radio host who is friendly with both Mr. Youngkin and Mr. Trump, credited Mr. Youngkin with refraining from adopting a combative Trump style while embracing issues critical to the Trump base, including some white voters\u2019 concerns over how the racial history of America is taught in schools.", "\u201cIf you look at Youngkin\u2019s campaign issues, they very much mirrored what is critical to America First voters and to the Trump voters\u2019 agenda,\u201d Mr. Fredericks said in an interview on Wednesday. \u201cHe did everything he could to embrace Trump voters, but we also understood he had a different style and a different tone.\u201d", "Republican voters came out in force not only across Virginia, where Mr. Youngkin\u2019s margins exceeded Mr. Trump\u2019s in every city and county in the state, but also in scores of other contests where the former president did not engage, including in New Jersey and on Long Island. Even in liberal Seattle, a Republican has a wide lead in the election for city attorney in a contest in which the Democrat ran on a platform of abolishing the police.", "Virginia\u2019s Republicans attributed their success less to Mr. Trump\u2019s sideline cheerleading for Mr. Youngkin and more to an environment fueled by disenchantment with the Biden administration, anger that the coronavirus pandemic shows few signs of receding and an economy that has seen rising prices for gasoline, among other household staples.", "It resulted in a Republican turnout that the party had spent years trying and failing to build when Mr. Trump was in the White House.", "\u201cWe spent a lot of money and time and effort trying to turn out Trump disengagers \u2014 people who voted for Trump in \u201916 and then didn\u2019t show up after that,\u201d said John Whitbeck, a former chairman of the Republican Party of Virginia. \u201cThey didn\u2019t vote in 2017, 2018 or 2019, but suddenly in the red areas, they showed up enthusiastically for 2021.\u201d"]
